qas.question: What was the capital of the Ptolemaic Egypt?
What was the capital of Seleucid Syria?
Alexander and Antioch were centers of what culture?
What leaders conquests widened the horizons of the Greek world?
What particular demographic emigrated to the new Greek empires?

context: During the Hellenistic period the importance of Greece proper within the Greek-speaking world declined sharply. The great centers of <a2_0>Hellenistic<a2_0/> culture were <a0_0>Alexandria<a0_0/> and <a1_0>Antioch<a1_0/>, capitals of Ptolemaic Egypt and Seleucid Syria respectively. The conquests of <a3_0>Alexander<a3_0/> greatly widened the horizons of the Greek world, making the endless conflicts between the cities which had marked the 5th and 4th centuries BC seem petty and unimportant. It led to a steady emigration, particularly of the <a4_0>young and ambitious<a4_0/>, to the new Greek empires in the east. Many Greeks migrated to Alexandria, Antioch and the many other new Hellenistic cities founded in Alexander's wake, as far away as modern Afghanistan and Pakistan.
